subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Macbeth

messageBody:
Thanks for your thoughts, Paige.
 
I'm afraid that I have to disagree about the virtues of a transliterating keyboard driver:  It is not optional, it is essential!  Even if you say that you are able to type "fairly quickly" in Jerome, I doubt you could do it well enough to be hired as an administrative assistant for a Read Alphabet-based office!  I'm thinking like a good 40-55 words per minute; This isn't attainable, because too many keys are on capitals. Forget the word "transliterating." The keyboard driver is simply the way keyboard must work in any language. Consider the fact that with upper case, we use 52 letters in English on 26 keys- our keyboard drivers interpret SHIFT + (letter) as a signal to put down a completely different symbol.  And in the many countries of the world, where there are far more characters than keys, E.g., China, Japan, Thailand, India, etc., several keystrokes are used to create a single complete character. This is always the case in Chinese and Japanese, where the elements of the radical characters are specified by single keystrokes, and drivers recognize combinations to create radical and more complex characters. Some of those languages, like Thai and Hindi, can present a trucated form of the writing (for example, omitting vowels, which are integrated into the shape of the complete character) by using simple keystrokes, but the full script must use multiple keys to create complete characters with the loops and flourishes which indicate vowels.  Semitic languages, like Hebrew and Arabic are a bit better off, since they normally are written without vowels, but the inclusion of the vowel of course, requires another letter keystroke.  Nearly half of the world's population uses non-Roman-based writing systems.  You can bet that if they're not hitting alt, shift, control all the time, they're hitting other combinations of characters a lot to flesh out the writing.  Even many European languages had to use backspace + (accent) on the typewriter to get all of their letters to appear correctly, since some Slavic languages can put an accent over almost every character.  The computer keyboard eliminates some of that awkwardness, you can keep going forward, and the keyboard can recognize a letter combination a signifying an accented letter. Esperantists usually use an x or an h to signify the accent, with h being the easier combination to type.
 
Or consider it this way: Stop thinking of the capital letters as "places" on the keyboard, and think about the actions that are required to produce a letter.  With only 26 letter keys, multiple keystrokes are going to be needed to produce most of the characters in a 62-character alphabet.  We're using the "Shift +" combination to do almost everything, when a simpler solution, not requiring the poor lil' ol pinky to do that work would be to simply type a logical character combination. 
 
Re Dvorak:  I'm the only person I know who actually tried it, and that was twice, as a matter of fact.  The second time was last year, and I converted my Windows systems both at home and work to the Dvorak schema.  I liked the more logical arrangement of the keys, and I definitely did get up to "fairly quick" typing with it, in the neighborhood of 30 words per minute.  But I abandoned it after about six months because I couldn't break that barrier, and on Qwerty, I can do 55 wpm easily.  I figured 6 months was adequate time for a trial! Dvorak has its own illogical parts too, like R and L being under the weakest fingers, and A being under a weak finger while U gets the prime real estate.  After my two shots at it, I think that in a non-Qwerty-biased world, it would be a superior alternative for someone who is just learning to type or one who has never achieved good speed with Qwerty.
 
>No one thinks of a "they" or "thaw" as "dh", and I feel it adds a
needless level of complexity. 
 
Since in Senior QS we have the blessing(?) of THREE "th's" Thoth, Thither, and Other (T, H, K),  I think the easily remembered digraphs of th, dh, and xdh would greatly simplify matters.  It seems a lot more sensible to me than Shift+T, Shift+H, and Shift +K, which we have now. It would be a slight exaggeration to say that I think in terms of  "dh" sounds, but as soon as one begins learning the sounds of the language, th and dh is a fairly common way of differentiating between the Thoth and Thither sounds in Roman letters. And the less unnecessary use of the Shift key, the faster and easier it goes for everyone. Another possible benefit of the transliterating driver would be that we could put the slash back where it belongs, and have the driver intelligently print a namer dot when it encounters a initial capital letter.  Thus, we could actually write things like and/or again without having to remember where the slash went, and the Shift key goes back to it's reasons for living--indicating capitals and punctuation, not letters.  Let letters and letter-combinations create letters, and Shift do punctuation selection, not letter selection.
 
 
That way, NO Read characters would have to be mapped onto punctuation keys, capitalization comes from natural use of the Shift key, and no punctuation marks are eliminated or even moved. 
 
Shush, Zhivago, Thoth, Thither and Church can be typed very naturally as sh, zh, th, dh, ch, which should be significantly easier to remember, and much easier to type than Cap S, Cap Z, Cap T, Cap H, small c!  They all occur in English except for dh, which once learned, won't be confused for anything else, and is quite intuitive.  Th is to dh, as t is to d, as tall is to deep, as unvoiced is to voiced. Inkling is usually represented in Roman by ng, which will do nicely.  The alternate forms, Noon, Up, and Other, could be designated by an x, which would be impossible to confuse in Shavian letters with any other meaning. Thus, xn, xa, xdh, or something similar. Again, easily remembered, x signifying "alternative form." The half-letters could be flagged by something else: say an initial h, which would give hw, hwh, hd, hz, ht, hp, hy, hh. Easily remembed: The half-letters are flagged by an initial h, for "half".
 
Finally, I heartily agree that the keyboard mapping can be improved.  It shouldn't be too difficult for me to create something a little more logical.  And I COMPLETELY agree that Read characters shouldn't be displacing punctuation symbols, no matter how infrequently used.  The problem is simple: 62 characters vs. an overwhelmed 26 letter keys.  As long as one is stuck with a mapping paradigm, the more letters, the more illogical placements (I really didn't WANT to put Other on Cap K!)
 
Although I love them, In QS, the ligatures are not necessary. eliminating them brings us down to 55 characters, still 3 over the letter key and SHIFT + letter key maximum.  The namer dot must stay on a key until we can get a Shavian driver to input it logically. Even then, it would be desirable to have a true place for it, to indicate it out of context, as a symbol per se.. The two most logical candidates to go are Read's Gaelic letters, which are a concession to Scottish, not English. One more must go.  What to do, what to do!
 
I won't ask you to part with half-Yo and half-wheat, Paige; you brilliantly extended Read's own logic here.  While Read seems to want to include the X's, I think one at least with have to go. You don't like them, I do, but we've got to make some room somewhere.  I'll sacrifice them--maybe put them into somewhere in the extended character set, like ALT + 0244 or something. 
 
There, we've got the room now, but the vowels will never make sense, sinse there's 15 unique Shavian letters for vowels and 5 appropriate keys.  I'll do the best I can, and it WILL be better than what we've had, but I consider this only a Band-Aid solution before a keyboard driver for the alphabet can be created.  Give me a few weeks, OK?  I've got a lot of pans in the fire, right now, a lot!
 
Shalom v'Tovah,
 
Jon

always do that which impels you most to love.
 
        --St. Teresa of Avila, The Interior Castle

Jon & Ewout:

I am not so sure  the idea of a transliterating keyboard driver is a good idea.  It reminds me of training wheels on a bicycle.  When I was five, I rode my bicycle for a year with training wheels attached to the rear wheel.  When my father finally took them off, we discovered I still did not know how to balance because the training wheels had kept me from  having to.  But after they came off, I learned to ride the same day.

I don't want to push this analogy too far, but just in the last few days after posting a few messages and texts in jerome, I have found my skill in typing with jerome has advanced  fairly quickly.  I still have a few letters I have to search for, but it will not take long before I will be able to type fairly easily in jerome.

I think it is best to write with Quikscript in mind rather than using some intermediate combination of letters which are then transliterated by a driver to produce the symbol you intend.    I believe very few people have actually tried to use jerome up to this point so no one has much experience with it.  I am a good touch typist and never look at the keyboard when I type.  I would assume, however, that it is probably more difficult to get used to the jerome keyboard mapping for a person who is not a touch typist since the Quikscript symbols do not appear on the keys.  Of course, the way one becomes a touch typist is by practice and watching the screen as one types.  So I believe anyone who is motivated can, with a moderate amount of practice, learn to type using the current jerome mapping.

Of course, in any touch typing, one should use the proper fingers on the appropriate keys, which requires the use of all eight fingers and one thumb.  I believe the average self-taught typist only uses three or four fingers so their hands are moving all over the keyboard, which makes it impossible to type quickly.  But there are innumerable typing programs, which can break them of this improper technique.  (I know:  it will difficult to tell someone to learn to type first, and then learn jerome touch typing.)  I am just voicing my opinion that it is better to touch type in jerome than it is to learn a series of alternate letter combinations representing one symbol, and the production of such a driver may lead to people not thinking with Quikscript in mind as they type.  And how will that affect how they handwrite in Quikscript in their own daily lives.  My concern is that the production of such a driver may actually be a shortcut that is detrimental to these individuals learning and utilizing Quikscript in the long run and, thus, will be detrimental to the spread of Quikscript.

Note:  As an interesting historical aside, we have been stuck with the Qwerty keyboard since the early days of typewriters.  I read that this ordering of keys was decided upon due to the poor mechanisms of those typewriters:  if you activated two keys next to each other too frequently, the mechanism tended to jam.  The Qwerty keyboard is actually poorly designed for fast typing as the vowels, with the exception of "a" are not on the home key row.  Obviously, this makes no sense as the vowels are the most used letters and moving your fingers off the home row takes more time.  There is an alternative keyboard, Dvorak, which is designed more scientifically.  After a touch typist makes the transition to Dvorak, their typing speed increases approximately 20% just from the improved key positions.   Since touch typing involves a connection between the mind and the appropraite finger position on the keyboard, one cannot use both the Qwerty and Dvorak keyboard depending on which is present on a particular machine.  In tests it took approximately two weeks for a secretary to make the transition to Dvorak.  Once she had, she was no longer able to type quickly on a Qwerty keyboard.  This, coupled with the natural conservatism of businesses and people in general, explains the absolute dominance of Qwerty.  The inertia of the mass of people who touch type using Qwerty because that is what has always been available have prevented Dvorak from making any inroads on Qwerty.

Moving to another point:  the problem I see with the present keyboard mapping for jerome is that Jon set it up to match the present Shavian mapping on the theory, I believe, that some of the people interested in Shavian who had already learned the existing Shavian mapping would make the shift to Quikscript.  I do not see any evidence of that happening on any significant scale, and the current mapping is not as felicitous for jerome as it could be.

The letters which jerome shares with roman should be set up for the same keys as much as possible to aid the shift from roman to Quikscript   There are twenty-six letters on the keyboard,and with the use of the shift key, this gives us fifty-two positions for letters.  I believe we should avoid the use of keys currently used for punctuation and other symbols unless absolutely necessary.  As an example, "wholewheat" is currently mapped on the "tilde" key.   This is a long stretch for the left little finger and does not aid fast typing.  Because it is a key little used in roman typing, it forces me to look at the keyboard, which a touch typist does not want to do.

Shavian has no half-letters so the Shavian mapping did not have to take that issue into account.  Since Quikscript does use half-letters, it would make sense to me that those letters should be produced by using the shift key along with the same key that produces the whole letter.  Example:  "peep" mapped to "p", "half-peep" mapped to shift "p."  "Day" and "half-day" to be mapped the same way on "d" and shift "d."  And so forth.

Jon, how much trouble would it be to remap a revision of jerome to work better for Quikscript?  I assume that the dificult part in producing the font was setting up the letter shapes and that the key mapping was a relatively straight forward process.  Is this correct?  If we made such a revision available on Read_Alphabet, those people prefering the Shavian mapping could continue to use it, and those who prefer an optimized Quikscript version could use it.  The recepient of a communication will not care how it is mapped.   People migrating from the Shavian group to the Read_Alphabet group could use the mapping they were already familiar with.  Those who are totally new devotees of Quikscript could use the revised mapping.  If doing this remapping is not a vast amount of trouble, I will work on a remapping scheme to see how the mapping can be improved.  I would like to do this before I spend too much more time using the present mapping.

Aside:  I have been working on Hamlet's soliloquy in Senior Quikscript.  The half-letters are working very well.  I also believe that some of the letters that I thought needed additional work look fine when a 12 point font is used.  In general, I am very pleased with jerome.

Sorry this was so long.   Sometimes I get started and can't seem to stop.

All the best to everyone,

Paige Gabhart
 
 

Jon Zuck wrote:

 Wow, Ewout!  This sounds excellent.  Is there anyone who can create such a
driver for us?

It sure would make using QS a lot easier.
 

Shalom v'Tovah,

Jon
http://surf.to/frimmin
 

> If somebody would create a driver, it can be programmed to return the
> 'they'-symbol when somebody types 'dh'. Two letters become one, but it
would
> indeed NOT require you to learn any keyboard map. You can just type a
roman
> reform and get proper quikscript returned.
>
> But someone will have to program this driver first. I certainly don't have
> the time/knowledge (yet) to do so.
>
> Ewout
